li.a: Continuing Education for Health Care Professionals
Continuing Education for Health Care Professionals

div.h1: What to do if you think you may have COVID-19

div.span: With a growing number of confirmed COVID-19 (coronavirus) cases in West Michigan and the United States, feeling sick can be scary. If you have symptoms like fever, cough or shortness of breath, we offer virtual screening and phone screening options for advice on what to do next. Please note: screening is required before a COVID-19 diagnostic test

div.h2: We are all in this together
div.p: At Spectrum Health, we’re working to support our community through the pandemic. Our goal is to help you and your family stay healthy and get the care you need.

div.span: What are the symptoms of COVID-19?

div.div: Symptoms of COVID-19 include fever and cough with or without difficulty breathing. Some people may also experience fatigue, body aches, diarrhea, runny nose or sore throat. Most people develop only mild symptoms. But some people, usually those with other medical problems, may develop more severe symptoms, including pneumonia.

div.span: Who is at higher risk for getting very sick from COVID-19?

div.div: People at higher risk include those:

ul.li: With underlying health conditions such as heart or lung disease, diabetes or obesity.

div.p: The CDC website has a comprehensive listing of people at higher risk.

div.div: What is the difference between a COVID-19 screening and a COVID-19 test?

The purpose of the COVID-19 screening is to determine your likelihood of having COVID-19. Screenings are completed by answering a series of questions. Your risk results are given to you immediately. A screening is not a COVID-19 test. A screening is required before a COVID-19 diagnostic test may occur.
If you have been screened and you have a doctor’s order, you may be eligible to be tested for COVID-19. The test is a laboratory test that can identify the virus that causes COVID-19. It requires a specimen collection including a swab of your nose. The specimens are tested at the Spectrum Health lab and results are available within 24 hours.
Should I be tested?

The Michigan Department of Health and Human Services recommends testing for people who have mild symptoms that are concerning related to COVID-19. The most common symptoms of COVID-19 are fever and cough with or without shortness of breath. If you have been exposed to someone with confirmed COVID-19 and are experiencing symptoms, you might have COVID-19. If you are concerned about your symptoms, call your doctor or call the Spectrum Health COVID-19 hotline for a free phone screening at 833.559.0659. For patients who need testing, we offer testing by appointment only.

div.span: How long should someone with COVID-19 be in home isolation?

ol.li: At least seven days days have passed since symptoms first appeared.
At least three days (72 hours) have passed with no fever (without the use of fever-reducing drugs) and your symptoms have improved.

div.span: Can I still make an appointment for regular care?

div.div:
We have enabled all our primary care and most of our specialty care medical teams to see you through a MyHealth virtual visit.
For needs that require an in-person visit, we have locations to see you including primary and specialty care, urgent care and labs.
To learn more about your regular care options and how to schedule, visit spectrumhealth.org/patientaccess or call 877-362-8362.
Spectrum Health in-person appointments for routine and non-urgent care, such as annual check-ups, routine monitoring and wellness exams will be deferred until further notice or when social distancing measures recommended by Governor Whitmer have been lifted. We also are postponing elective outpatient surgeries and procedures.
Do I have to wear a mask when entering Spectrum Health hospitals and clinics?

div.p: Yes. To protect our team members and patients from increasing community spread of COVID-19, every person entering Spectrum Health hospitals or clinics receive a standard isolation mask at entrance screening stations.

div.div: As a visitor, can I wear my own mask or a homemade face mask when entering a Spectrum Health hospital or clinic?

div.p: To best protect our team members and patients from increasing community spread of COVID-19, please wear the standard isolation mask provided to you upon entering. Homemade face masks should only be worn in non-clinical settings. By wearing your own mask, you are accepting the risk that it may not be adequate protection.

div.div: Can I be with my loved one in the hospital?

div.p: Visitors, including family members, are currently not allowed at all locations including hospitals, outpatient locations and long-term care facilities, except in special circumstances. Special circumstances that allow one visitor include pediatrics, maternity (labor and delivery) and patients having surgery. Visit our family and visitor restrictions page to learn more, including ways to virtually connect with patients.
